pullRequest.body:
Following `LinearAlgebra.Dual` this makes `NormedSpace.Dual` reducible.

nodes.body:
@mattrobball could you add a TODO as discussed on Zulip?
bors d+

:v: mattrobball can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

I've started a discussion at https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Typeclass.20search.20is.20affected.20by.20other.20subexpressions/near/389833387, maybe just link to that thread instead of an issue.
Added with references to leanprover/lean4#2522.
!bench

:v: mattrobball can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/4ec9e81b-95b3-43e2-b296-f91e2f1e69c0) for commit 8caab6403f73134110c5a9287b29db214a48d17e.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/1b838738-3e14-4867-b465-eff70df7a0e0/to/4ec9e81b-95b3-43e2-b296-f91e2f1e69c0) against commit 844436b8e934723791c651c28ca914a34873857d:
```diff
  Benchmark                                     Metric         Change
  ===================================================================
- build                                         maxrss          31.1%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Adjoint   instructions    60.0%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Dual      instructions    62.3%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.Dual            instructions    12.7%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.WeakDual        instructions    19.1%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.VonNeumannAlgebra.Basic     instructions    12.0%
```
That maxrss might mean we are trying to compile more declarations than before. Let me investigate before moving forward. Thanks for the thought to test the performance.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/b437e49f-5c69-484d-a573-0d7f92ebb6c4) for commit 5cd01506e7f569d8b992f5458635d16884e1a95e.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/1b838738-3e14-4867-b465-eff70df7a0e0/to/b437e49f-5c69-484d-a573-0d7f92ebb6c4) against commit 844436b8e934723791c651c28ca914a34873857d:
```diff
  Benchmark                                                           Metric         Change
  =========================================================================================
- build                                                               maxrss          30.0%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Adjoint                         instructions    60.0%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Dual                            instructions    62.4%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.LinearPMap                      instructions     5.1%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.Dual                                  instructions    12.7%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.WeakDual                              instructions    19.1%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.VonNeumannAlgebra.Basic                           instructions    12.0%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.FilteredColimitCommutesFiniteLimit   instructions    -5.1%
```
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/6eab045e-7459-41d0-a28f-0690fa651d11) for commit 2008326690e9a749122395c7614650adafb5bce8.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/1b838738-3e14-4867-b465-eff70df7a0e0/to/6eab045e-7459-41d0-a28f-0690fa651d11) against commit 844436b8e934723791c651c28ca914a34873857d:
```diff
  Benchmark                                        Metric         Change
  ======================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Adjoint      instructions   -18.7%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Dual         instructions    62.3%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.LinearPMap   instructions     5.0%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.Dual               instructions    12.7%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.NormedSpace.WeakDual           instructions    19.1%
- ~Mathlib.Analysis.VonNeumannAlgebra.Basic        instructions    12.0%
```
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  Build succeeded!

  The publicly hosted instance of bors-ng is deprecated and will go away soon.

  If you want to self-host your own instance, [instructions are here][instructions].
  For more help, visit [the forum].

  If you want to switch to GitHub's built-in merge queue, visit [their help page][gh].

  [instructions]: https://github.com/bors-ng/bors-ng#how-to-set-up-your-own-real-instance
  [the forum]: https://forum.bors.tech
  [gh]: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/configuring-pull-request-merges/managing-a-merge-queue



  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6151251025/job/16690923353)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6151251025/job/16690923098)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6151251025/job/16690922860)

bors d+

I think we should merge this even if performance is a little worse, but should maybe wait just in case it's really terrible.

```suggestion
    dual space: 'NormedSpace.Dual'
```
seems more useful here

At first I was confused about whether we wanted the construction of the dual as type or the Hilbert space structure on the the dual of a Hilbert space. 

But I guess the original was neither of these things?
I think the original thing probably meant the dual of a Hilbert space as a Hilbert space, so that you can state the Riesz representation theorem as an isometry of Hilbert spaces.
@PatrickMassot, do you prefer `ContinuousLinearMap.toNormedSpace` or `NormedSpace.Dual` here?
I think `NormedSpace.Dual` is better. Again the intended would be a combination of a Inner product space and a complete space instance, but we don't have a single declaration that would fit.

```suggestion
    LinearIsometryEquiv.coe_toContinuousLinearEquiv, Function.comp_apply, toDual_symm_apply]
```
This is just `rfl` though, right?
No, `toDual_symm_apply` is far from rfl.
Fixed the spacing
Does something below timeout if this is absent? If so, can you make it clear that this "helper" is to resolve a performance problem?

It fails on line 77:
```
failed to synthesize instance
  Norm (Dual ùïú E ‚ÜíL[ùïú] Dual ùïú E)
```
With a failure or a timeout? (I can't open lean right now)
It failed quickly. I didn't check further.

That line can be fixed with:
```lean
theorem inclusionInDoubleDual_norm_eq :
    (by exact ‚ÄñinclusionInDoubleDual ùïú E‚Äñ) = ‚ÄñContinuousLinearMap.id ùïú (Dual ùïú E)‚Äñ :=
  ContinuousLinearMap.op_norm_flip _
```
This feels like a bug to me; somehow the TC search on the LHS is breaking the search on the RHS

The next failure in the file is even worse:
```lean
--ok
#check ContinuousLinearMap.norm_id_le (ùïú := ùïú) (E := Dual ùïú E)

theorem inclusionInDoubleDual_norm_le : ‚ÄñinclusionInDoubleDual ùïú E‚Äñ ‚â§ 1 := by
  rw [inclusionInDoubleDual_norm_eq]
  -- fails
  have := ContinuousLinearMap.norm_id_le (ùïú := ùïú) (E := Dual ùïú E)
  exact this
```
Referenced leanprover/lean4#2522 in the file

```suggestion
abbrev Dual : Type _ := E ‚ÜíL[ùïú] ùïú
```
Eric, could you explain what the type ascription is meant to do here?

It's a stylistic change for the reader: lean doesn't care.

It's meant to make it clear that we're defining a type; but more generally, the convention in mathlib is to pretty much always write the full type to help the reader. For example, we prefer to write `def choose (m n : ‚Ñï) : ‚Ñï := sorry` instead of `def choose (m n : ‚Ñï) := sorry`. This is just another case of the same thing.
I added the signature.
Ideally we'd have a tracking issue for "we made X noncomputable due to a maxrss issue"
Where do we want it?
I think mathlib4 is fine, unless you want to open a Lean4 one. We can always link from the mathlib one to the lean one at a later date.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat (NormedSpace.Dual): make `Dual` reducible

source.title: Spikes in compilation + maximum resident set size
